awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Understanding and Managing Ecosystem Change at the Forest-Peatland Ecotone
awd_abstract_narration:
This doctoral dissertation improvement project will investigate the impacts of changing environmental conditions on the patterns and mechanisms of forest loss and subsequent peatland expansion in temperate and other non-boreal regions.  Using a variety of methods, the doctoral student will reconstruct and compare fire-climate-vegetation dynamics of the past century to those that have occurred over the past millennium.  The results of this project will reveal whether once-forested but now peat-accumulating sites are novel ecosystems, or whether such transitions have occurred in the past in these regions, possible due to drought conditions and fire frequencies that are similar to those observed today.  These results are of interest to land managers, who require tools to determine how best to manage altered ecosystems. By identifying whether (and which) ecological thresholds have been crossed, this project will provide crucial input for decision-making regarding best practices for land management.  The doctoral student will work closely with regional land managers and other stakeholders, including land owners and educators, to ensure that project results are available to inform collaborative land use decisions.  The PIs will also engage K-12 and college students in hands-on fieldwork, thus preparing future scientists to employ multiple lines of evidence in investigating the causes and consequences of environmental change.  In addition, as a Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement award, this award will provide support to enable a promising graduate student to establish a strong independent research career.

The overarching objective of this doctoral dissertation improvement project is to contribute to the scientific literature on alternative stable states that result from changes in the fire regimes of forested ecosystems.  Using methods from paleoecology, dendroecology, and community ecology, this research will examine fire-mediated effects on ecosystem structure at varying spatiotemporal scales at the peatland-forest ecotone, a transition zone that, like tree line, is particularly sensitive to changes in fire and climate.  The project addresses the following questions: (1) How has fire activity during post-European settlement periods with distinct climate conditions differed quantitatively from that of pre-settlement conditions?  (2) How has fire impacted the vegetation community of the forest-peatland ecotone during the most recent extreme warm/dry and cool/wet periods?  (3) What are the mechanisms that favor a transition from forested to peat-accumulating lands in a site?  Specifically, the doctoral student will use tree-ring fire scar dates, forest stand structure reconstructions, and sedimentary records to answer these questions.  In addition, surveys of present-day vegetation composition/structure at control and burned sites will be paired with those of abiotic and biotic factors to uncover the mechanisms underlying the persistence of the peat-accumulating state.  Although this project will focus on the forest-peatland ecotone of southwestern Patagonia, the research will provide new insights and approaches for dealing with the interactive effects of environmental change in many other regions, including some in the United States.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Recurring wildfires are expected to increase under climate change in hyperhumid and cold temperate rainforests globally, yet there is little information on the drivers of postfire establishment, floristics, and overall resilience or transition in these temperate systems. The overarching goal of this doctoral dissertation project was to investigate whether and how altered climate and fire regimes have caused a striking and long-lasting shift in ecosystem structure from dense temperate rainforests to non-forested peat-generating wetlands across lowland sites in southwestern (SW) Patagonia.  Our research questions and methods were designed to reveal climate-fire-vegetation relationships over three spatio-temporal scales:  1) Paleoecological methods (i.e., fossil pollen and charcoal counts from lake sediment core samples representing 20 to 40 year intervals) to examine whether landscape-scale shifts in broad vegetation community classes from about 1100 AD to the present were associated with changes in climate (e.g., warmer/drier periods vs. cooler/wetter periods) and/or peaks in fire activity.  2) Dendroecological methods (i.e., fire scars and tree-ring counts) to examine similar interactions between climate, fire and tree establishment, but at finer resolutions (i.e., site-specific annual tree establishment dates over the past 400 years).  3) Field observations of abiotic and biotic conditions of a control and a repeatedly-burned site to model the factors affecting tree seedling abundance and test specific mechanisms through which sites may transition from forested to non-forested states.  Additionally, we monitored seedling vigor, height and mortality across seven years within an experimental plantation in the burned site.

The results of this project contribute to the scientific understanding of the ecological dynamics of an understudied forest-peatland ecotone and a globally-threatened conifer while filling knowledge gaps about the ways in which fire shapes vegetation change in poorly-drained sites located in climatically wet biomes.  In contrast to boreal peatlands, temperate peatlands in general and those of the Southern Hemisphere in particular have received relatively little study.  Our literature review and fieldwork suggest that the structure of the forest-peatland ecotone of SW Patagonia responds to changing fire/climate regimes similarly to that of forest-peatland ecotones in SW Australia and New Zealand, hinting at common mechanisms.  In SW Patagonia, many sites along river valley bottoms that were once dominated by the long-lived tree Pilgerodendron uviferum (included on the IUCN?s Red List of Threatened Species) are now dominated by the peat moss Sphagnum magellanicum (Figure 1). Past research on this post-fire vegetation shift found evidence that raised water tables, which resulted from burning/loss of tree canopies and reduced evapotranspiration rates, were the cause of forest regeneration failure. However, our major preliminary results indicate that a) there are no statistical differences in water table depths between vegetation patches that span the forest-peatland ecotone at the control and burned sites, including between patches that vary in the density of P. uviferum seedlings; and b) percent cover and height of S. magellanicum lawns and hummocks may negatively impact forest regeneration by exposing young seedlings to desiccation during periods of drought and/or through competition as fast-growing, densely-packed S. magellanicum stems envelope slower-growing P. uviferum seedlings.

Results from the paleo- and dendroecological components of our project have been hampered by challenges associated with conducting research on and in wetland ecosystems.  For one, our ability to distinguish historic shifts from one type of wetland to another (e.g., forested wetland to non-forested peatland), rather than only between the broader ecosystem classes of wetland versus non-wetland, may not be possible given a lack of modern pollen ratios for indicator taxa (i.e., for bryophyte and vascular plant species that occur across various wetland types in SW Patagonia).  In addition, our field sites were characterized by deep organic soils or peat moss lawns that obscured tree bases and induced horizontal growth in P. uviferum, thus generating high levels of uncertainty in coring heights, ring counts and establishment dates.  We are currently finalizing Bayesian state-space models that incorporate novel process variation and observation error, including ageing uncertainty, which will let us examine tree establishment as a function of time-since-fire and large-scale climate modes.

Broader impacts of this project included junior scientist training, local outreach and engagement via tree planting with a middle school in SW Patagonia, and conference presentations. Ultimately, the results of this project will reveal whether once-forested but now peatland sites are novel ecosystems, or whether such transitions have occurred in the past in SW Patagonia, possibly due to drought conditions and fire frequencies that are similar to those observed today.  These results are of interest to land managers, who require tools to determine how best to manage altered ecosystems, including which interventions will be most appropriate (e.g., restoration to forest, promotion of carbon storage, or peat moss extraction). By identifying whether (and which) climate-fire-vegetation feedbacks have changed, this project will provide crucial input to help land managers understand current and future ecosystem structure, and thus best practices to support desired ecosystem services.
